title: Meet the vampire who went viral during a visit to Salem
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Matthew Pruno, a Long Island cosplayer, went viral after a photo of him in Salem as a vampire was shared online.
Pruno's social media following grew to over 15,000 after his Salem visit, where he cosplayed as Louis from 'Interview with a Vampire'.
Pruno has embraced his viral success, planning more cosplay appearances and updating his Instagram to reflect his vampire persona.

title: Boston history quiz: How much do you remember from the past 30 years?
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Boston.com marks 30 years with a history quiz on major events in Boston since 1995.
The quiz challenges participants to arrange key Boston events in chronological order.
Content producer Kelly Chan developed the quiz to engage readers with interactive multimedia content.

title: New on Netflix and more: Top streaming picks for November 2025
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Netflix introduces 'Back to the Future,' 'Frances Ha,' and 'Game Night' on November 1, 2025.
Boston.com highlights Massachusetts Halloween-themed movies like 'Hocus Pocus' and 'The Witch' recommended for streaming.
Streaming platform recommendations include recent titles such as 'Thanksgiving' on Hulu and 'Hereditary' on HBO Max.

title: Rhamondre Stevenson misses multiple practices ahead of Falcons-Patriots
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Rhamondre Stevenson missed three consecutive practices, leaving his playing status uncertain for the Patriots' game against the Falcons.
Stevenson leads the Patriots with 279 rushing yards and three touchdowns but has been struggling with fumbles.
Rookie Treveyon Henderson and Terrell Jennings are expected to lead the backfield if Stevenson is ruled out.

title: NFL execs believe Patriots are for real, but are a year away from Super Bowl contention
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots have started the NFL season 6-2, with quarterback Drake Maye emerging as an MVP candidate.
NFL executives consider the Patriots a playoff contender but not yet ready for Super Bowl contention this season.
ESPN's FPI gives the Patriots a 2.6% chance to win the Super Bowl and 6.8% to represent the AFC.

title: Before Election Day, meet Boston’s City Council candidates
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's municipal election is on Nov. 4, with residents voting for City Council and unopposed Mayor Michelle Wu.
Eight candidates are competing for four at-large City Council seats; most districts feature contested council races.
Residents can find polling locations and verify registration online; polls open at 7 a.m. and close at 8 p.m.

title: Boston.com readers still pay for their adult children’s phone bills â€” and they’re not happy about it
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com readers shared diverse opinions on adult children remaining on their parents' phone plans.
A WhistleOut survey shows 22% of American adults are on their parents' cellphone plan, down from 34% in 2022.
Some parents view phone plans as financial support, while others see it as a burden or hinderance to independence.

title: Longtime political analyst Jon Keller among latest WBZ layoffs
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Jon Keller, a WBZ-TV political analyst for 20 years, was laid off amid company-wide cuts by Paramount.
Paramount, owned by Skydance Media's David Ellison, laid off 2,000 workers nationwide, according to The Wall Street Journal.
Keller, known for moderating major debates, also writes for MASSter List and previously worked at WLVI-TV.

title: Boston City Council District 7 race: Miniard Culpepper and Said Ahmed
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Said Ahmed and Miniard Culpepper are running for the Boston City Council's District 7 after Tania Fernandes Anderson's resignation.
Ahmed highlights the housing crisis as a primary issue for District 7, proposing tenant protections and affordable housing initiatives.
Ahmed emphasizes community engagement and transparency to restore public trust in the City Council, proposing regular town halls.

title: Boston City Council District 6 race: Ben Weber and Steven Berry
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Incumbent Ben Weber faces challenger Steven Berry in Boston's District 6 City Council race.
Steven Berry emphasizes housing as a major issue and advocates for zoning changes to increase housing supply.
Berry identifies as a working-class candidate with no political ties, highlighting underrepresentation of his demographic.
